Items to be evaluated:
IELTS speaking test part: Part 1
Topic: Place you live in
Questions:
Tell me about the street where you live
What are the public transports services near your street bike?
Would you like to live on the street for a very long time?

Answers:
I live in a magnificent street, it's called Vitebskaya, and it's in the coolest neighborhood in St. Petersburg.
This is a great question, um, because, uh, actually we do not have many, um, opportunities to get to the city center very quickly from the area where I live, but I see it as an advantage, um, well, it makes the neighborhood quieter, and, um, I don't know, it, um, I walk more because of that.
Yeah, this is what I'm debating right now to be honest. Um, I've enjoyed living there, but um, I think it's essential to move like every three or four years. So I've lived there for two years and a half, so probably I should, yeah, I should get going soon.

Topic: School trips
Questions:
What was your favorite school trip when you were a child?
What makes it a good school trip?
Did you take the same kinds of school trips as your parents?
Have any types of school trips become more popular these days?

Answers:
Ah, with your school trip, well, um, can I, can I tell about the university trip? So it was a hike, um, we went to the mountains and we spent there four days. That was my first experience hiking and, uh, since then I've, I've really, um, yeah, I've done it a lot.
It was very well organized. I felt safe and I got all the equipment, all the instructions, and also there were great people with us and great leaders.
I don't think so. I don't think my parents have ever been to the mountains because, um, that wasn't in Russia, that wasn't in this area, it was in America. So my school was, um, like located pretty much at the footstep of a mountain, and, uh, my parents did not study next to mountains, so no.
In Russia, yeah, I think these days schools have more opportunities to take the schoolchildren abroad and I definitely don't think that was like a common practice at the time when my parents were children.

Topic: Fashion
Questions:
Do you consider yourself to be a fashionable person?
Is being trendy important in your country?
Are the most popular people in life the most fashionable?
Is it easy to be fashionable without spending a lot of money?

Answers:
Yes and no I think sometimes when you don't pay too much attention to fashion you just appear to be fashionable but when you kind of give it a lot of thought it's kind of seems a little bit too how to say too too enforced
Some people may say so, um, in St. Petersburg where I live there are many trendy people and there are many, um, shopping malls and, I don't know, like designer boutiques where you can get, um, pretty like interesting clothes. Also people buy clothes abroad, um, but being trendy is not that important to me personally.
Of course not. I don't think so. Why not? Well, look at, I don't know, look at some of the, um, look at some of the, uh, businessmen who, um, who we see, um, yeah, in the media. I think they dress really, really simple and make a point out of it.
Absolutely, thrift stores rule.

I've been living in this city since September last year, so that's about five months, I'd say.
In the near future, I don't think so. I'm quite happy where I am. I've got a nice job, so that's, I don't see any reason to move.

In my daily life I would say my pin code, door codes, and some phone numbers I suppose.
I've never been very good with numbers but as soon as I get in the habit of typing something in I can usually remember.
Definitely not. I was not very good at maths and my dad actually had to help me quite a bit to get a good mark.
I think it's quite important that I can handle numbers but my job doesn't fully focus on numbers as a main priority it's it's important that I'm not number blind but I I can I think I'm alright.

Answers:

Probably about once a week, I can catch a bus from my place to the shopping center where it's located.

Topic: Daily routine
Questions:

Answers:
My daily routine... well, I'm a student, so my classes start at 8, and that means so during the week I usually get up about 6:30, have a quick shower, get dressed, catch a bus to university. I am always running late, so I don't have time for proper breakfast, I just grab a coffee. I have classes all day and get home at about 5 pm, and after dinner I usually try to do some study.
The afternoon, definitely. I'm not really a morning person, it takes a while for me to wake up properly.
I suppose I should try to make more time for a proper breakfast in the morning because by mid-morning I get really hungry.

input:
Evaluate the following answer(s) for IELTS speaking test for the rubric "Grammatical Range and Accuracy".

Items to be evaluated:
IELTS speaking test part: Part 1
Topic: Place you live in
Questions:
Where do you live in your country?
Is it an interesting place to live?
Would you live there in the future

Answers:
I live in Hyderabad, which is the capital of Andhra Pradesh in the southeast of India. It is a very big city, about 7 million people live there.
Oh yes, a very interesting place to live. Hyderabad has a very long history, so there are lots of ancient forts, mosques, and other monuments. There is a very beautiful lake, and there are also lots of wonderful markets.
Yes, I think once I finish my studies here, I'll go back to Hyderabad. My husband is from Hyderabad too, so I think we'll stay there.

Topic: Hobbies and interests
Questions:
What hobbies and interests are popular in your country?
Which hobbies and interests do you enjoy?
What hobbies and interests did you have as a child?
Do you think parents should encourage their children to have a hobby or interest?

Answers:
People have many different pastimes in my country. I think the most popular these days are things like gardening and do-it-yourself, which is when people, well, usually men, make things for their home. I think women tend not to have too many hobbies. You can't really call shopping a hobby. I think in the past, women used to fill up the leisure time that they had with craft activities, but sewing and knitting aren't so common these days. I think reading is still very popular, especially now these days with the new e-readers.
Um, well, like a lot of people, my work takes up a lot of my time and at the weekend I like to meet up with my friends or go out with my husband so I don't really have much time for hobbies. But I do read a lot, especially history and biography. Also, I love collecting art so I go to a lot of art fairs. I really like colorful abstract art which really brighten up our homes.
Gosh, uh, that was a long time ago. Let me think. Uh, I used to collect keyrings. I think I had about twenty or twenty-five. They were silly things really, but fun for a small child. Uh, I used to like painting and drawing. My parents were very supportive and they bought me a lot of oil paints, but I'm not really very talented. I also played the clarinet. I was in a junior orchestra. I remember once we, uh, we played a concert and my reed broke during the first piece, and so I couldn't make any sound.
Oh yes, very much so. I think it is very important for children to have something other than school, television, and computers. Sometimes a hobby can turn into a very successful career, but even if it doesn't, it can help the child develop as a person as they learn about new things and meet new people who share the same hobby.

Topic: Weather
Questions:
Do you prefer hot weather or cold?
Which time of year did you enjoy the most as a child?
Has the weather changed much in your country in recent years?

Answers:
Ah, I think I prefer cold weather. I know most people prefer hot weather, but it is always so hot in my country that it is such a nice change to feel the cold. Of course, in the cold, it's very easy to put on a hat and gloves to keep ourselves warm. Tell me about the weather in your country at different times of year. India is so big that there are many different climates, so I'll just talk about the weather in Hyderabad. Generally, we have a tropical wet and dry climate. That means that the summers, March to June, are hot, over 30 degrees and very humid. Sometimes it can reach over 40, which is just unbearable. At the end of the summer, the monsoon comes, and it rains for about three months. After the rainy season, it's winter, which is quite short, just a couple of months.
Well, I think like most children, I would say the summer, when we had the long school holiday. But I always preferred spring. There's something so lovely about when everything starts to grow again after the winter. You can almost smell it in the air.
I don't think so really. I know that in some countries the climate has been changing because of global warming, but where I live it seems to be the same. Just heat and rain. I have noticed something, in recent summers when it's very hot, there have been many water shortages. I don't remember that happening when I was younger.
output: Band score Grammatical Range and Accuracy: 9.0

Items to be evaluated:
IELTS speaking test part: Part 3
Topic: Attitudes to gift
Questions:
Can you tell me something about how people feel when they receive a homemade gift and when they receive a shop-bought gift?
Do you think children gain more pleasure receiving gifts than adults do?
Do you think that more people get more pleasure giving or receiving gifts?

Answers:
Well, I think as with everything, it depends on the person and the gift. When a grandchild makes something for their grandparents, like a bookmark or a clay pot that they've made at school, then obviously their grandparents will treasure it. For adults, I think it's a bit different. If people are going to give homemade gifts, then they need to be of really good quality. Why do you say that? Well, when children make things, it's the thought that counts. But when it's adults making things, it has to look like the present is a proper present, rather than something they've made just because it's cheaper. Of course, the thought still counts, and in many ways, our time now is more important or precious than money. So if somebody has spent a lot of time making a gift, it will mean a lot. But if someone has made some chutneys or pickles or some other type of food, then it has to be edible and taste nice as well. Most gifts these days are shop-bought, and there isn't really anything wrong with that. What is important, I think, with a shop-bought gift is that the person buying the gift should spend some time thinking about what the other person would really appreciate. It's no good a husband going into a perfume shop and buying the first perfume he likes. He needs to see what perfume his wife is wearing. That shows his wife that he's paying her attention.
Yes and no. Obviously children love receiving gifts but children do generally get a lot of gifts. Children these days are spoiled and they get too many gifts. So the more gifts they get the less they value them. Adults on the other hand generally have the resources to buy things for themselves. So if they really want something they can buy it. Of course this then makes present buying for adults much more difficult but of course there are things that we'd like that we can't really afford or we can afford them but can't justify their expense. For women it might be perfume or a day at the spa or a new pair of party heels. For men usually something to do with their hobbies or books or CDs.
Oh, um, this is a tricky one. Well, I think most people get pleasure out of both. Of course it depends. We may not get a lot of pleasure out of giving gifts to children who we know may not appreciate them. But, uh, if we have found the perfect gift for someone we love and we know it's going to make them happy, well, then this will really fill our hearts with joy. Um, similarly, if someone receives a gift of something that they don't really want or they can sense that it has been bought out of haste, then this isn't really going to make them feel that good. But if it's something wonderful, then, well, of course, they're going to feel fantastic about it.

Although, a lot of young people like to be given new phones and other gadgets, so if a parent isn't sure which model to get, then they could be influenced by advertising.
Oh yes, definitely. Yes, um, in fact, I think it's much worse than that. It's not just the old festivals becoming commercialized, but so-called new ones being created just for the sake of present-giving. Things like Valentine's Day and Mother's Day, these aren't Indian traditions, but suddenly we find we have to buy a present for our spouse on Valentine's Day. And while it is nice to recognize how important our mothers are, surely it should be something we do every day, not just once a year when we buy her some chocolates.

There are so many dangers for both adults and children. Another danger is cyber bullying and there have been many victims of this. Many children also become addicted to computer games.
Of course, children are too young and don't think of the dangers. They believe everything they hear or see. For example, if they're talking with somebody they don't know and who pretends to be a good guy and asks them to meet with him somewhere, they will possibly go. If that person is not who he says he is, they may get into big trouble.
Yes, parents can do many different things to make sure their children are okay. They should put the computer somewhere and not in the child's bedroom. Then they can watch what their child is doing. Also, parents should talk to their children and tell to them the dangers of internet so that way the kids must know what to do and what not to do and be more careful. Another thing is that parents must have good relationship with their children so they can tell them if anything strange or unusual happens.
They should be allowed but they must be aware the dangers. If parents give them some valuable advice such as to not share internet passwords with anyone, to not reply to rude messages, to not post inappropriate photos and things like that, then there won't be any problem. But parents must always know of what their children are doing.
Well there is more to expect from it. I don't know what but I'm sure there's still much more to come since it started. input:
Evaluate the following answer(s) for IELTS speaking test for the rubric "Grammatical Range and Accuracy".

Items to be evaluated:
IELTS speaking test part: Part 2
Topic: -
Question:
"Describe a gift or a present that someone gave you recently.

You should say

what the occasion was
who gave it to you
what it looked like
and explain how you felt about receiving it."

Answer:
I'm going to talk about a present my husband gave me last year for my birthday. We had gone to Istanbul for a few days. My husband had always wanted to go there. Anyway, we had a few days holiday from work and we decided to fulfill my husband's dream. As I said earlier, I'm really interested in art and so even though I had no real desire to go to Istanbul, I was totally captivated by all the beautiful buildings and the wonderful arts and crafts that were available there. The Blue Mosque was my favorite building. From the outside, it looks just like a typical Ottoman mosque, but inside it is quite startling. The large windows with the light reflecting on the exquisite blue tiles made it just breathtaking. I asked one of the guides about the tiles and she told me that they were from Iznik and that they are still made today. When we left the Blue Mosque, we walked down a pedestrian lane full of shops, including some tile shops. In one of the shops, the owner told us that the tiles were made in Iznik. Anyway, one of the tiles really caught my eye. Actually, it sang to me. It was of fish, four big fish and lots of little ones, all in different shades of green. I really, really wanted it. But when we asked the price, it was very high, something like 300 American dollars. Obviously, I knew we could negotiate, but it seemed such a high price that we just left. The next night, we went out for my birthday meal. Just as we were finishing the dessert, the waiter came over and handed me the most beautifully wrapped gift. I knew at once, because it was very heavy, that it was the fish tile.

Question:

Answer:
So my experience on my adventure probably will be in all the Asian area. I would love, as I said, to see all the Japanese culture. I really love the way they think, the way they act, the way they are so organized. Probably it's because it's so different from my country. So I think that that is really something that makes me want to go to the country. I want to know the culture and visit everything. Probably I will choose one of my best friends that is called Borja. I've been with him since we were three years old, so we went together to school, we went together to university. So he's kind of another brother for myself. And I think that we all, we both want to see the same things and we want to experience the same kind of things. So I will take him with me. Probably we don't need that big equipment or skills or abilities because it's just like normal traveling, it's just knowing the culture, just mixing with local people. I think that that's the best thing that you can do to really know the culture and really know the country. So I will say that the only thing that you need is a bag, so we'll be backpacking. That is really interesting. And I would say that the most important thing is just to understand the way they think, just to see why they do things, why they do that type of sushi, why they love that food. It's something that really makes the whole experience something unique and different. And actually, that's the thing that later you can tell your friends, like, I know Japan, I don't, I know all the tourist place, but I know as well that little village nearby the sea where no one have ever been, just the local people. And I think that that's the magic of traveling and that's the magic of seeing different things.

When, when you go to a temple, I, I wear, like, pure simple clothes because that is the tradition. So, that, that makes me feel, like, really peaceful and calm because most of the time you wear, like, simple clothing when you go to a temple. So, it makes me feel calm when I wear those clothes.
